lines.content: >_Stratify is more than just a task organizer; it's a seamless experience designed to amplify your productivity._
* :computer: **Command-Line Simplicity**: A user-friendly, command-line-input based interface ensures efficient task handling without unnecessary complexities.
* :watch: **Effective Task Management**: Stratify empowers you to effortlessly manage your tasks, providing a streamlined approach to boost your productivity.
* :bust_in_silhouette: **User-Friendly Design**: Easy to use, Stratify eliminates the learning curve. Dive in, follow a few simple steps, and let it transform how you manage your tasks.
1. **Clone the Repository**: Fetch Stratify to your local machine effortlessly from [here](https://github.com/tituschewxj/ip).
1. **Compile and Run**: Quick setup with minimal effort.
1. **Add Your Tasks**: Seamlessly integrate your to-dos, deadlines, and events with just a few commands.
1. **Let it Manage for You**: Sit back as Stratify efficiently orchestrates your tasks, allowing you to focus on what truly matters.
- [x] :date: **Deadline Tracking**: Stay ahead by managing crucial deadlines.
- [x] :people_holding_hands: **Event Coordination**: Seamlessly integrate and manage your events.
Are you a Java programmer looking for a practical playground? Stratify has you covered. Enhance your Java skills by running it's simple `main` method:
>Elevate your task management with Stratify â€” where simplicity meets productivity.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/chatbot/Launcher.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Launcher.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'

>_Stratify is more than just a task organizer; it's a seamless experience designed to amplify your productivity._
efficient task handling without unnecessary complexities.
Stratify empowers you to effortlessly manage your tasks,
providing a streamlined approach to boost your productivity.
Easy to use, Stratify eliminates the learning curve.
Dive in, follow a few simple steps, and let it transform how you manage your tasks.
<!-- For the links to work in both IntelliJ and GitHub pages, there should be a double space. -->
1. Ensure that you have Java 11 or above installed on your computer.
1. Copy the jar file into the folder that you want to use as the home directory for Stratify.
1. Open up a command terminal, `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in,
and use the `java -jar stratify.jar` command to run the application.
A GUI similar to the below should appear.
Displays your task list, with all your added tasks within.
> * This lists all the tasks in your task list.
> * This ends the chat, disabling the input, and prompts the user to exit.
Adds a named todo, into your task list.
> * This adds a todo of the name `homework` into your task list.
Adds a named deadline, with a by date, into your task list.
> * The `<by_date>` does not need to be a date, but can be formatted as a date.
>   * The supported date formats are `MMM d yyyy` and `yyyy-MM-dd`.
> * This adds a deadline of the name `read book`,
> with a deadline by `Friday` into your task list.
Adds a named event, with, into your task list.
> * The `<start_date>` and `<end_date>` do not need to be dates, but can be formatted as dates.
>   * The supported date formats are `MMM d yyyy` and `yyyy-MM-dd`.
> * This adds an event of the name `cs2103t tutorial`,
> with the start date at `1pm` and end date at `2pm`,
> * The <index> must be a valid index from the task list,
> meaning that the task must exist.
> * This marks the first task from your task list.
> * The <index> must be a valid index from the task list,
> meaning that the task must exist.
> * This marks the first task from your task list.
Deletes a task from your task list.
> * The <index> must be a valid index from the task list,
> meaning that the task must exist.
> * This deletes the first task from your task list.
Finds a task from your task list.
> * This finds and displays all tasks with the substring
> `work` in it, such as `homework`, `working`, or just `work`,
> in the name of the task.
> * It doesn't find from other argument values, such as `<by_date>` in a deadline.
Undoes a change that you have made.
> * `/by <steps>` is an optional argument, so it does not have to be included.
> By default, if not included, it rolls back one change at a time.
> * The `<steps>` is the number of steps to rollback by, which should be a positive integer.
> * You can only undo changes from the current session.
> * This undoes the previous change, which is creating a todo called `assignment`,
> * The task list is rolled back to its previous state, before that todo was created.
> * This undoes the previous two changes, which is creating a deadline called `homework`
> * `list` does not modify the anything, so is not included as a change.
> * The task list is rolled back to its previous state, before the todo and deadline were created.
The chatbot can be resized to fit your screen, by resizing the window.
The data is saved as a human-readable file in `[JAR file location]/data/save.txt`.
Advanced users can modify the data file directly.
> If the format of the save file is invalid, your save file will be discarded and replaced with a new save file,
> with an empty task list. It is recommended to have a backup of your save file if you have modified it directly.
> **Q**: How can I undo a change that I made?
> **A**: Use the `undo` command to roll back your change.
> **Q**: How can I transfer my data to another device?
> **A**: Copy over the save file, and your data should be transferred.
> **Q**: Why does save file fail to load?
> **A**: Your save file is either in the wrong format, or stored in the wrong location.
> **Q**: How can I tell if my command was successful?
> **A**: If your command is successful, there will be a success message. Otherwise, there would be an error message.
Command refers to some text that a user can input, which results in the execution of some action,
and displays something in the chat. The execution can be either successful or unsuccessful (gives error message).
* `name` refers to a word, or a group of words, that are within brackets or after a forward slash.
* The `name` at the start of a command refers to the name of the command.
* `name`s are trimmed, whitespace before and after it are removed.
* Square brackets (`[`, `]`) around an argument represents an **optional** argument, which does not have to be included.
* Angled brackets (`<`, `>`) around a `name` represents the name of the value of the argument.
* Forward slash `/` followed by a `name` represents the name of the argument.
Argument refers to some text that starts with a forward slash, followed by possibly brackets, in the command line.
* For example, in a deadline command, `/by today` is an argument with the name `by` and passes the value `today`.
The name of the value is `by_date`.
* Arguments can be in **any** order, for example, `event cs2103t tutorial /to 2pm /from 1pm`.
* If the **same** argument is provided more than once, only the first instance of that argument is read.
For example, in `deadline cs2103t quiz /by today /by tomorrow`, the `by_date` is read as `today`,
* Invalid or missing arguments (and their values), will display an error to the user.
* This encapsulates the behaviour of a chatbot,
* which is the handling of the message content and executing commands.
private static final TaskList USER_TASK_LIST = LocalStorage.loadTaskList();
/** Store the main window of the chatbot. */
private static final MainWindow MAIN_WINDOW = new MainWindow();
* Gets the response message given a command line input string from the user.
* This will close the application if the command is to end the chat.
* Executes the action to execute from the command line input,
* @throws ActionException If the input is invalid.
private void executeCommand(String commandLineInput) throws ActionException {
PrintFormatter.addLogToMessageQueue("Chat has ended. Close the chat to exit.");

Action(Command command, SuppliedArgument... suppliedArguments) throws ActionException {

final <T extends StringValue> T findArgument(String name) {
// It is safe to cast to T as the argument value has already been

* Finds the default {@link Argument} of this action.

* @return The value of the default {@link Argument}.

* If no error is thrown, the execution is successful.
* @param taskList The {@link TaskList} that is used with the chatbot.
* @throws ActionException If the action fails certain validation checks due to invalid input.
public abstract void execute(TaskList taskList) throws ActionException;

* This represents an abstract {@link Action} that takes an index as it's default argument.

throw new AssertionError("The value should have already been validated as an integer!");

* This represents exceptions specific to {@link Action},
* which are thrown when invalid input results in an {@link Action} being invalid,
* and is unable to recover a valid state.
public abstract class ActionException extends ChatBotException {
* This represents exceptions due to an invalid argument value in an {@link Argument}.
public final class InvalidArgumentValueException extends ActionException {
/** Stores the reason for the invalid value. */
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} with an invalid {@link Argument} value.
* @param command The associated {@link Command} with that argument.
* @param invalidArg The {@link Argument} with the invalid value.
public InvalidArgumentValueException(Command command, String invalidArg, String reason) {
return "OOPS!!! The argument value <" + invalidArg + "> of `" + command.getName() + "` is invalid!\n"
* This represents exceptions due to a missing {@link Argument} in an {@link Action}.
public final class MissingArgumentException extends ActionException {
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} with a missing {@link Argument}.
* @param command The associated {@link Command} with the argument.
return "OOPS!!! The argument `/" + missingArg.getName() + "` of `" + command.getName() + "` must be present!\n"
* This represents exceptions due to a missing argument value
* for an {@link Argument} in an {@link Action}.
public final class MissingArgumentValueException extends ActionException {
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} with a missing {@link Argument} value.
* @param command The associated {@link Command} with that argument.
* @param missingArg The {@link Argument} with the missing value.
return "OOPS!!! The argument value <" + missingArg.getValue() + "> of `"
* This represents exceptions due to the presence of a value
* in an {@link Argument} that does not require a value.
public final class UnexpectedArgumentValueException extends ActionException {
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} for an unexpected {@link Argument} value.
* @param command The associated {@link Command} with that argument.
* @param argument The {@link Argument} with the unexpected value.
return "OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I didn't expect <" + argument.getValue() + "> :-(\n"
* This represents exceptions due to an unrecognized argument name in the {@link Action}.
public final class UnrecognizedArgumentException extends ActionException {
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} for unrecognized {@link Argument} names.
* @param command The associated {@link Command} with that argument.
* @param argument The {@link Argument} with the unrecognized name.
return "OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what `/" + argument.getName() + "` means :-(\n"
* This represents exceptions due to an unrecognized {@link Command} in the input.
public final class UnrecognizedCommandException extends ActionException {
/** Stores the name of the unrecognized {@link Command}. */
* Constructor for this {@link ActionException} for unrecognized commands.
return "OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what `" + unrecognizedCommandName + "` means :-(";
* This stores a {@link Command} argument's name, and it's associated value.
* <li>If the name matches the command, it is defined to be the default argument.

* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
// null represents the value that isn't there

* @param value The value of this argument, which can be null.
* Checks if the other argument has the same name as this.

* @return True if the name is the same, otherwise false.
* Returns the human-readable string of this.

/** Stores the usage hint for this. */

* @param arguments The {@link Argument}(s) of this command.
// Name of the argument is the first argument

* The usage hint is generated when the command is constructed,

// remove redundant slash at the start

// missing argument exception if the argument is expected and mandatory
* Casts the {@link SuppliedArgument}(s) to their expected type.
* @throws InvalidArgumentValueException If the value cannot be cast successfully.
* This encapsulates the behaviour of an {@link Argument} that a {@link Command} can expect.
* <li>An ExpectedArgument list generates the usage hint for a {@link Command}.
/** Stores the type of the value of this. */
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} without a value.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} with a value and name.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* @param valueUsageName The value of this argument, as a descriptive name of its purpose.
* @param expectedType The expected type of the value of this argument, which is a subtype of StringValue.
public ExpectedArgument(String name, String valueUsageName, Class<? extends StringValue> expectedType) {
* Validates the supplied {@link Argument} using this expected argument for the presence or lack of a value.
* If this value is null, then no value is expected.

* @param suppliedArgument The other {@link Argument} to compare with.
* @throws ActionException If the {@link Argument} has a missing or unexpected value.
public void validateArgumentValue(Command command, Argument suppliedArgument) throws ActionException {
// else argument is valid and we do nothing
* Represents an argument of a command that can be expected, but is optional.
* <li>Optional arguments are wrapped in {@code [square brackets]} to indicate that they are optional.
* <li>The default argument is never an {@link OptionalArgument}.
public final class OptionalArgument extends ExpectedArgument {
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} without a value.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} with a value and name.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* @param valueUsageName The value of this argument, as a descriptive name of its purpose.
* @param expectedType The expected type of the value of this argument, which is a subtype of StringValue.
public OptionalArgument(String name, String valueUsageName, Class<? extends StringValue> expectedType) {
* Represents the arguments generated from the command input,
* which are then supplied to the action,
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} without a value.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* Constructor for this {@link Argument} with a value and name.
* @param name The name of this argument, which should not be null.
* @param value The value of this argument, which can be null.
* Casts the stored argument value to the expected type.
* @throws InvalidValueTypeException If the value cannot be cast successfully.
public void castValue(ExpectedArgument expectedArgument) throws InvalidValueTypeException {
// no need to cast if value doesn't exist
// all StringValue and subclasses constructors should take in a String.
throw new AssertionError("StringValue and subclasses constructors should exist!");
throw new AssertionError("All JAR files should be properly signed with the same certificate!");
throw new AssertionError("StringValue and subclasses constructors should be accessible!");
throw new AssertionError("StringValue and subclasses constructors "
+ "should have a valid argument passed into them!");
throw new AssertionError("StringValue and subclasses should be able to be instantiated!");
// the only exception that can be thrown is InvalidValueTypeException
* This represents exceptions thrown by a {@link ChatBot}.
public abstract class ChatBotException extends Exception {
* Gets the message of this exception, which can be printed to the console.
* This handles functional programming with exception handling for {@link ChatBotException}s
* as Java doesn't provide a default implementation which use functional programming with exception handling,
* @param <T> The type of input to the function.
* @param <R> The type of output of the function.
* @param <E> The type of exception thrown by the function.
public interface ThrowableFunction<T, R, E extends ChatBotException> {
* Performs the operation on the given argument of type T,
* returning an object of type R.
* @throws E If an exception E is thrown.
* Parses the input of a {@link ChatBot} into {@link Argument} list.
* Parses the input line into it's {@link Command} and {@link Argument}(s).
* @return An {@link Action} containing the {@link Command} and it's {@link Argument}(s).
* @throws ActionException If invalid input is provided that results in
public static Action getParsedInput(String commandLineInput) throws ActionException {
// command is always the first word in the input
* Parses the {@link Argument}(s) from an input line.
* <li>"/" is a special character, when at the start of a word, it denotes the start of an {@link Argument}.
* <li>"/" not at the start of a word, will not be recognized as a special character.
// scan through each word, check if it is an argument
// first word is always argument name
* Parses an {@link Argument} consisting of the argument name and value.
* @param argumentName The string representing the {@link Argument} name.
* @param argumentValue The string representing the {@link Argument} value.
* @return The {@link Argument} for the action, that is formed.
private static SuppliedArgument parseArgument(String argumentName, String argumentValue) {
* Parses the stored input line into a {@link Task}.
/** Stores the pattern to match a {@link TaskList} item. */
private static final Pattern TASK_ITEM_PATTERN = Pattern.compile("\\d+\\.(?<task>.*)");
